metadata.product: TIJN Blue Light Blocking Glasses Square Nerd Eyeglasses Frame

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: Hi Casey, thank you so much for taking the time to speak with me today. My name is Jessica, and I’m calling from TIJN Eyewear. We really appreciate you agreeing to chat with us about your recent experience with our blue light blocking glasses. I’ve read your review, and first and foremost, I’m truly sorry to hear that our product not only didn't meet your expectations but actually seemed to worsen your symptoms.

transcript.speaker: Casey
transcript.text: Uh, yeah, no problem. Thanks for reaching out. I honestly didn't expect anyone to call after I, you know, left such a… scathing review. But I'm happy to talk about it.

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: Not scathing at all, Casey. It’s incredibly valuable feedback, and we take all customer experiences very seriously, especially when they highlight significant issues. We really want to understand what happened. To start, could you tell me a bit more about what initially motivated you to purchase these particular glasses? You mentioned reading articles and needing something for your long screen hours.

transcript.speaker: Casey
transcript.text: Right. So, yeah, like I said in the review, I'm a freelance graphic designer. My whole life is basically screens. I'm staring at a big monitor, then my laptop, then my phone, pretty much all day, every day. I was getting these, like, super intense headaches, especially in the afternoon, and my eyes just felt constantly dry and tired. I'd heard a lot about blue light blockers helping with that.

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: And what made you choose our TIJN brand specifically, over other options you might have seen?

transcript.speaker: Casey
transcript.text: Hmm, good question. I mean, there are *so* many out there, right? I think… well, honestly, the look was a big thing. The square frames, they fit my kind of "nerd chic" vibe, you know? And the price point was really appealing. Some of the other ones I saw were, like, way more expensive, and I figured, "What's the harm in trying a cheaper option first?" If it worked, great, if not, I wasn't out too much money.

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: That makes perfect sense. So, the style and affordability were key factors. When they arrived, you noted they felt lightweight, almost flimsy, but you weren't expecting premium materials. What was your very first impression when you actually put them on? You mentioned the yellow tint.

transcript.speaker: Casey
transcript.text: Oh, the tint. Yeah, that was… immediate. I put them on, and it was like everything suddenly had this sickly yellow filter. Whites were creamy yellow, and I could tell other colors were off too. As a designer, that was a huge red flag right away. Color accuracy is paramount for my work, obviously. I even hesitated right then.

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: I can definitely see how that would be a concern for your profession. Despite that initial worry, you decided to give them a fair shot. You wore them for three days. Could you walk me through what happened during those days? How did your symptoms evolve?

transcript.speaker: Casey
transcript.text: Yeah, so I tried to power through it. I thought, "Maybe my eyes will adjust, maybe the benefits will outweigh the color issue." Boy, was I wrong. Within the first day, my eyes felt… not better, but almost *more* strained. And the headaches – they just got worse. By day two, they were throbbing behind my eyes, radiating to my temples. It wasn't just tension anymore; it was a sharp, persistent pain.

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: That sounds incredibly distressing. You described them as "sharp, throbbing pains." Can you elaborate on the difference between these headaches and the ones you were experiencing *before* wearing the glasses?

transcript.speaker: Casey
transcript.text: Before, they were more like a dull ache, a general pressure from staring at screens for hours. Annoying, but manageable with breaks. With the glasses, it was like a focused pain, almost like my eyes were trying too hard to… I don't know, process what they were seeing through the tint. It was sharper, more intense, and just constant from the moment I put them on until I took them off. And even then, the residual pain lingered.

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: So, they seemed to actively exacerbate the very problem you were trying to solve. You also mentioned a "strange, subtle glare on the inside of the lenses." Can you describe that glare a bit more? Was it constant? In specific lighting conditions?

transcript.speaker: Casey
transcript.text: Oh, that. Yeah, it was weird. It wasn't like a direct reflection, but more of a faint, almost hazy glow on the *inside* of the lenses. Like a ghost image, almost. It was subtle enough that I couldn't always pinpoint it exactly, but it was *there*, lurking in my peripheral vision, especially when there was a light source behind me or to the side. And it definitely contributed to the overall visual fatigue. My eyes just felt tired trying to look past it.

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: That's a very specific detail, and something we definitely need to look into. You also mentioned your partner tried them on and experienced a "weird eye feeling." Did they describe it similarly to your experience, or was it different for them?

transcript.speaker: Casey
transcript.text: He didn't get the headaches like I did, thankfully. He just wore them for about an hour while browsing online. But he definitely said his eyes felt "off" and "uncomfortable." He couldn't articulate it beyond that, but it was enough for him to take them off pretty quickly. So, yeah, it wasn't just me being overly sensitive, I guess.

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: That’s helpful context. It suggests it might be a general lens characteristic rather than something unique to your specific eye condition. Before purchasing our glasses, what strategies or methods were you using to combat eye strain and headaches?

transcript.speaker: Casey
transcript.text: Honestly, not much specifically for blue light. I'd try to take breaks, sometimes use eye drops for the dryness. And just, like, trying to remember to blink more. I’d adjusted my monitor brightness and used night mode on my phone, but those things only helped a little. I was really hoping the glasses would be a more significant solution.

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: I see. So you were looking for something more proactive. Given your experience with our product, what do you think would have made these glasses effective or even just tolerable for you? What specific improvements come to mind?

transcript.speaker: Casey
transcript.text: Okay, well, the most obvious one is the tint. If it had been truly subtle, almost invisible, that would have been a game-changer. I mean, if they're meant for people who work with screens, especially creatives, color distortion is just a no-go. And I've seen other blue light glasses that claim to have clear lenses, so it's clearly possible.

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: So, minimal to no color distortion is a critical improvement. Anything else?

transcript.speaker: Casey
transcript.text: Yeah, definitely the glare. That internal haze or whatever it was, it was distracting and just made everything feel... fuzzy? Also, maybe the material could feel a bit sturdier? I know I wasn't expecting premium, but they felt like they could snap easily. That's a minor point compared to the vision issues, but still. And, um, yeah, just something that doesn't actively make my head hurt more! That's kind of a baseline, right?

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: Absolutely, that's more than a baseline, it's the core functionality. You talked about the price point being appealing. If these glasses had worked perfectly for you – meaning no headaches, no tint issues, clear vision – would you have felt the original price was a good value despite the lighter frame material?

transcript.speaker: Casey
transcript.text: Hmm, that’s a good question. If they *worked*? Oh, for sure. If they had actually alleviated my headaches and eye strain, I would have been thrilled. I'd probably even buy another pair, honestly, to have as a backup or for different bags. The original price would have felt like a steal for that kind of relief. It was only because they made things worse that it felt like a complete waste. The concept is great, you know? It’s just the execution that didn't work for me.

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: That’s a really helpful distinction. It sounds like the *potential value* was high, but the *realized value* was zero due to the performance issues. Thinking about competitors, what would compel you to try another brand of blue light glasses in the future? What would they need to promise or deliver?

transcript.speaker: Casey
transcript.text: Well, definitely what I just said: no tint or an imperceptible one. A clear lens would be the dream. And obviously, they'd have to not give me headaches! Maybe some kind of, like, independent certification or a clearer explanation of *how* their filtering works, so it feels more trustworthy. And, um, good reviews that specifically mention long-term comfort for people who spend hours on screens. I’d probably be willing to pay a bit more next time, too, if there was a stronger guarantee of quality and effectiveness.

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: That makes sense. Building that trust back would be key. You mentioned you've since stopped using our glasses and your headaches have begun to subside. Roughly how long did it take for you to notice an improvement after you stopped wearing them?

transcript.speaker: Casey
transcript.text: I’d say almost immediately. Within a day or two of going back to, you know, just my regular vision and no glasses, the sharpness of the headaches started to ease up. It took maybe another couple of days for them to go back to my "normal" level of screen-induced discomfort, which is still not ideal, but definitely better than what I experienced with your glasses.

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: That’s a clear correlation, and it truly helps us understand the severity of the issue you faced. Casey, this has been incredibly insightful and thorough. Is there anything else you’d like to add, or any other feedback you think would be important for us to know?

transcript.speaker: Casey
transcript.text: I don't think so, no. I mean, I think I covered everything in the review and then some here. I just really wanted them to work, you know? It's a real problem for me and a lot of people in my line of work.

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: We completely understand, and your feedback is truly invaluable as we look to improve our products. On a scale of 1 to 10, with 1 being extremely dissatisfied and 10 being extremely satisfied, how would you rate your overall satisfaction with the TIJN blue light blocking glasses based on your experience?

transcript.speaker: Casey
transcript.text: Hmm, based on my experience, where they actively made things worse and didn't even deliver on the basic promise… I’d have to say a 1. Maybe a 0 if that were an option, but definitely a 1.

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: Thank you for your honesty, Casey. We genuinely appreciate you taking the time today and providing such detailed and candid feedback. It’s exactly this kind of insight that helps us identify where we need to improve. We'll be taking all your points into serious consideration.

transcript.speaker: Casey
transcript.text: Okay, glad I could help.

transcript.speaker: Jessica
transcript.text: Thanks again, Casey. Have a great rest of your day.

transcript.speaker: Casey
transcript.text: You too. Bye.
